Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Effective Data Tracking in the Regulation of Food Supply Chains

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, which trains a graduate student in methods of conducting empirically-grounded scientific research, explores the factors that influence effective data tracking in the regulation of food supply chains. The ever more prevalent outbreaks of food-borne illnesses have caused consternation across the world over the safety of our food. For example, in 2014, the European Union (EU) alone issued 3,792 food recall alerts, ranging from dangerous bacteria to defective packaging. These threats of food contaminants have pushed the World Health Organization and the United Nations to incorporate food traceability - the ability to track a food product's origins - into their initiatives for assuring a secure global food supply. Public health officials view documentation about food's origins and pathways as a necessary component of controlling risk within the supply chain. In practice, however, food traceability regulation often does not take the values of safety, quality, and knowledge of food producers into account. Understanding how the local conditions of food production conflict with food safety regulation is critical for developing better policies to protect all Americans from the dangers of food contaminants.

In this project, Gregory Kohler, under the supervision of Dr. Keith Murphy of the University of California at Irvine, will investigate the dynamics of data collection and regulation of food supply chains. Through an ethnographic study of a dairy cooperative, Mr. Kohler will examine how food traceability operates both as a tool for knowledge production and as a mechanism of governance by looking at the ways food traceability has expanded outside the realm of health into supply chain management more generally. The methods include participant observation in the dairy cooperative headquarters and member farms, interviews with farmers, managers, inspectors, and regulators, video-based linguistic anthropological data collection and analysis, and behavioral experiments involving the collaborative analysis of video and audio data with informants. Besides increasing scientific knowledge of the societal effects of food regulation on farming communities, findings from this research will inform debates surrounding the role of data tracking in constructing knowledge across various issues, including food, national security, and quality control.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the complex social, political, and technical arrangements undergirding global food safety regulation. This analysis provides invaluable perspective as the development of long-term food safety policies and infrastructures continues to challenge governance at local, national, and international scales. During the study, the co-PI studied how various national and transnational bodies, such as the Food and Agriculture Organization, the European Union, certification bodies, and food producers, shape food policy. Due to the complex links between regulators, corporations, food producers, and consumers, food policy provides a window into growing populist anger over technocratic governance. This study informs policy debates on these questions by looking at the ways food regulation often takes place outside democratic governance mechanisms through transnational bodies. In addition, it looks at the fraught politics over data control, as food producers increasingly look to collect more data along the food chain, often raising suspicions from other stakeholders, such as farmers and consumers. This project shows how new data collection software gets implemented on farms and the tensions that arise as a result.

 

Findings from this project are likely to impact theory and research in anthropology by making contributions to existing knowledge on food regimes, corporate governance, and standardization. In particular, this project examines how new technologies of governance operate at an interactional level by looking at the ways regulators, company employees, certification inspectors, and farmers interact during audits, inspections, lab analyses, and meetings. The co-PI applies video methods and interaction analysis from linguistic anthropology to studying the ways people contest, or align with calculative governance logics. Through these methods, the project sheds light on the different ways actors establish trust with one another, contest or align with certain rationalities, and negotiate together notions of safety and quality. This study will contribute to anthropological literature on identity, power, and bureaucracy by focusing in particular on the ways people bridge local values with institutional oversight in their everyday work routines. In this way, it will add insights into the new forms of sociality that might emerge as the EU food regime changes. While this study focuses on food traceability, it will help illuminate the role security discourses might play in framing tracing practices more generally. By studying how food tracing shapes notions of security, this project brings new attention to anthropology’s focus on power and the security state.
